text: Dark amber color with a medium head. Aroma is orange, floral, a bit of honey. Flavor of barley and caramel. Quite dry. Fairly bitter.

Tap at Macs Industrial in a pint glass. Think frothy off white head thats sporting an impressive cling. Malty with a minor smoke element. Sweetness coming though in toffee and caramel. Mouthfeel is thicker than anticipated with much more of a lager base. Taste is definitely representing the amber style with heavy fall characteristics. End is mild but mostly malt notes. Pretty standard Schells fare.
Draft. Clear golden amber color, creamy tan head. Aroma of caramel biscuit. Taste is bitter toast.
Bottle at the MN Renaissance Festival. Moderately hopped amber with nice caramel malt. This grew on me.
Sampled at Northgate Andover beer tasting. Literally no hops in this beer at all. Strike one. Still, its light and refreshing overall.

At All Pints North. I asked the brewer what style of beer this was, and suggested Vienna. he said it had too many hops for that. I think the Amber lager is a good label nonetheless. It is well hopped, but not like a well hopped pale lager, such as Arminius. The malt has a lightly roasted quality, and is on the dry side. Great palate.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 7-15-15. Pours a clear bronze to light amber with a moderate amount of cream to light taupe-colored head. Good lacing. Quite nice appearance. Pleasant, simple, mineral aroma features a dry caramel scent. Dry, cracker, soda water flavor. Smooth in the palate. Not as crisp as a lager should be. Very simple beer that did not elicit many notes from me. Its pleasant enough but not at all outstanding. Im not really understanding the early high ratings.

(bottle) Pours a clear amber color with a nice medium off-white head that stays well. Aroma is composed of gummie bears and iced tea (in that order), along with a little prune vibe, toasty malt, and some candied apple. All of these scents are meshing, and theyre meshing quite well. Flavor is not as "meshed" as the aroma, but its still quite fine with a more prominent iced tea character, caramel, minerals, barley(?) towards the back that takes on a bit of a breakfast cereal finish (one of those no-frills, no sugar types) at the very end. A little hop sting here as well. Overall I had low expectations for this beer, but they were more than met and Ill even say were exceeded. Good on Schell for making this more than a run-of-the-mill beer.

12oz bottle pours a bright clear Amber with a medium khaki head. Aroma lightly fruity hops, light resin, and dry caramel malt. Taste of dry earthy caramel and toffee malt, with a light hop fruitiness, hop bitterness well balanced with the malt, and light yeast. Im impressed for the style.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2016 I am really loving this beer. I agree with the 1st reviewer it would appeal to APA drinkers. Since APA and Vienna Lagers are two of my favorite styles and Schells is one of my favorite brewerys I was excited about this one. Taste reminds me of Mirror Pond pale ale. Clean tropical hops, nice malt balance, drinks easy and is just delicious. Will be a regular for me.

Bottle. First one to rate the new anniversary beer from my favorite regional brewery. Pours rich amber with off-white head. Good lasting rocky head Nose is surprisingly citrusy - with orange peel and some fresh hop resin notes. Flavor is quite simple and straightforward with no appreciable flaws. Single bready barley malt upfront meets afforementioned citrus hops with just a bit of sweetness in the middle. Finish is all citrusy hops with a touch of bitterness. A very good hoppy vienna that would greatly appeal to APA drinkers - a nice crossover but also just a very nice clean darkish lager in its own right. Ill have another.
